document_metadata.description: A knowledge assembly of biological entities involved in the innate and inflammatory immune responses and their relation to epilepsy.
document_metadata.name: Epilepsy - Innate and Inflammatory Immune Response

links.evidence: In this study, we investigated the effect of miR-132, miR-146a, and miR-155 on myeloid-related protein-8 (MRP8) induced astrocyte-related inflammation. Using quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) and western blot, we found clear upregulation of TLR4 and downstream inflammatory cytokines, along with dysregulation of miR-132, miR-146a, and miR-155 in in vitro astrocytes after exposing them to different concentrations of MRP8

In this study, we investigated the effect of miR-132, miR-146a, and miR-155 on myeloid-related protein-8 (MRP8) induced astrocyte-related inflammation. Using quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) and western blot, we found clear upregulation of TLR4 and downstream inflammatory cytokines, along with dysregulation of miR-132, miR-146a, and miR-155 in in vitro astrocytes after exposing them to different concentrations of MRP8

Using quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) and western blot, we found clear upregulation of TLR4 and downstream inflammatory cytokines, along with dysregulation of miR-132, miR-146a, and miR-155 in in vitro astrocytes after exposing them to different concentrations of MRP8

Using quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) and western blot, we found clear upregulation of TLR4 and downstream inflammatory cytokines, along with dysregulation of miR-132, miR-146a, and miR-155 in in vitro astrocytes after exposing them to different concentrations of MRP8

In this study, we investigated the effect of miR-132, miR-146a, and miR-155 on myeloid-related protein-8 (MRP8) induced astrocyte-related inflammation. Using quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) and western blot, we found clear upregulation of TLR4 and downstream inflammatory cytokines, along with dysregulation of miR-132, miR-146a, and miR-155 in in vitro astrocytes after exposing them to different concentrations of MRP8

The role of Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) in the activation of innate immunity has been extensively studied in the past several years. Here, we are the first to report that myeloid-related protein 8 (MRP8), an endogenous TLR4 ligand, is involved in the epileptogenesis of mesial temporal lobe epilepsy (MTLE)

The role of Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) in the activation of innate immunity has been extensively studied in the past several years. Here, we are the first to report that myeloid-related protein 8 (MRP8), an endogenous TLR4 ligand, is involved in the epileptogenesis of mesial temporal lobe epilepsy (MTLE)

In this study, we investigated the effect of miR-132, miR-146a, and miR-155 on myeloid-related protein-8 (MRP8) induced astrocyte-related inflammation. Using quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) and western blot, we found clear upregulation of TLR4 and downstream inflammatory cytokines, along with dysregulation of miR-132, miR-146a, and miR-155 in in vitro astrocytes after exposing them to different concentrations of MRP8

Together, our findings demonstrate the novel role of TLR4-related microRNAs, especially miR-132, in the regulation of MRP8-induced astrocyte activation and highlight the importance of miR-132 in the modulation of innate immune response induced by endogenous ligands in neurological diseases.

Using quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) and western blot, we found clear upregulation of TLR4 and downstream inflammatory cytokines, along with dysregulation of miR-132, miR-146a, and miR-155 in in vitro astrocytes after exposing them to different concentrations of MRP8

Astrocyte activation, associated with the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines interleukin 1-Î² (IL-1Î²), interleukin-6 (IL-6), and tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-Î±), is a hallmark of multiple brain diseases, including mesial temporal lobe epilepsy.

These results suggest that dysregulation of ADK in astrocytes is a common pathologic hallmark of TLE. Moreover, in vitro data suggest the existence of an additional layer of modulatory crosstalk between the astrocyte-based adenosine cycle and inflammation.

The major findings in our study were increased levels of IL-1Î², IL-6 and IL-1Ra in epileptic patients and high levels of IL-1Î² in TLE group. Our results support the existence of a chronic inflammatory state in epileptic patients.

These results suggest that dysregulation of ADK in astrocytes is a common pathologic hallmark of TLE. Moreover, in vitro data suggest the existence of an additional layer of modulatory crosstalk between the astrocyte-based adenosine cycle and inflammation.

Binding of TSPO is increased both ipsilateral and contralateral to seizure foci in patients with TLE, suggesting ongoing inflammation. Anti-inflammatory therapy may play a role in treating drug-resistant epilepsy.

Modulation of miR-146a expression by transfection of astrocytes with anti-miR146a or mimic, regulated the mRNA expression levels of downstream targets of miR-146a (IRAK-1, IRAK-2 and TRAF-6) and the expression of IRAK-1 protein.

In this study, we investigated the effect of miR-132, miR-146a, and miR-155 on myeloid-related protein-8 (MRP8) induced astrocyte-related inflammation. Using quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) and western blot, we found clear upregulation of TLR4 and downstream inflammatory cytokines, along with dysregulation of miR-132, miR-146a, and miR-155 in in vitro astrocytes after exposing them to different concentrations of MRP8

Together, our findings demonstrate the novel role of TLR4-related microRNAs, especially miR-132, in the regulation of MRP8-induced astrocyte activation and highlight the importance of miR-132 in the modulation of innate immune response induced by endogenous ligands in neurological diseases.

As a crucial component of brain innate immunity, neuroinflammation initially contributes to neuronal tissue repair and maintenance. However, chronic inflammatory processes within the brain and associated blood-brain barrier (BBB) impairment often cause neurotoxicity and hyperexcitability.Mounting evidence points to a mutual facilitation between inflammation and epilepsy, suggesting that blocking the undesired inflammatory signaling within the brain might provide novel strategies to treat seizures and epilepsy. Neuroinflammation is primarily characterized by the upregulation of proinflammatory mediators in epileptogenic foci, among which cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2)/prostaglandin E2 (PGE2), interleukin-1Î² (IL-1Î²), transforming growth factor-Î² (TGF-Î²), toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4), high-mobility group box 1 (HMGB1), and tumor necrosis factor-Î± (TNF-Î±) have been extensively studied.

The role of Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) in the activation of innate immunity has been extensively studied in the past several years. Here, we are the first to report that myeloid-related protein 8 (MRP8), an endogenous TLR4 ligand, is involved in the epileptogenesis of mesial temporal lobe epilepsy (MTLE)

To explore the role of innate immunity in the mechanism of epilepsy, the pentylenetetrazole (PTZ) kindling rat model was established using intraperitoneal injection of PTZ. The expression levels of TLR2, TLR4, and STAT molecules in rat hippocampi were analyzed using qRT-PCR and western blotting techniques. The expression levels of SOCS-1 and SOCS-3 in rat hippocampi were analyzed using qRT-PCR. RESULTS: Our data demonstrated that both the mRNA and protein expression of TLR2 and TLR4 were significantly upregulated in the rat hippocampus with PTZ injection, which was accompanied by an inhibition of SOCS-1 and SOCS-3 and an upregulation of STAT3.

The role of Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) in the activation of innate immunity has been extensively studied in the past several years. Here, we are the first to report that myeloid-related protein 8 (MRP8), an endogenous TLR4 ligand, is involved in the epileptogenesis of mesial temporal lobe epilepsy (MTLE)
In the present study we investigated the role of miR-146a, a key regulator of the innate immune response, in the modulation of astrocyte-mediated inflammation.
Our results show that miR-132 is a negative feedback regulator of IL-1Î² and IL-6, but not TNF-Î±, by targeting IRAK4.
In addition, the expression of IL-6 and COX-2 upon IL-1Î² stimulation was suppressed by increased levels of miR-146a and increased by the reduction of miR-146a.

These results suggest that dysregulation of ADK in astrocytes is a common pathologic hallmark of TLE. Moreover, in vitro data suggest the existence of an additional layer of modulatory crosstalk between the astrocyte-based adenosine cycle and inflammation.

Binding of TSPO is increased both ipsilateral and contralateral to seizure foci in patients with TLE, suggesting ongoing inflammation. Anti-inflammatory therapy may play a role in treating drug-resistant epilepsy.

To explore the role of innate immunity in the mechanism of epilepsy, the pentylenetetrazole (PTZ) kindling rat model was established using intraperitoneal injection of PTZ. The expression levels of TLR2, TLR4, and STAT molecules in rat hippocampi were analyzed using qRT-PCR and western blotting techniques. The expression levels of SOCS-1 and SOCS-3 in rat hippocampi were analyzed using qRT-PCR. RESULTS: Our data demonstrated that both the mRNA and protein expression of TLR2 and TLR4 were significantly upregulated in the rat hippocampus with PTZ injection, which was accompanied by an inhibition of SOCS-1 and SOCS-3 and an upregulation of STAT3.

Furthermore, TLR9 deficiency exacerbated seizure-induced cognitive decline and recurrent seizure severity. Our findings thus suggest the existence of bidirectional communication between the innate immune and nervous systems for the maintenance of adult brain integrity.
